title: Swash Helvetica
content:
Has anyone designed swash caps that would go with Helvetica?

Yes, I know this is a bit riduculous, but I'm not entirely convinced that it's a foolish idea.

I've found Canterbury Swash Sans, which is a step in the right direction. Anything else?
author: Jonathan Clede

comments.content:
You want Helvetica Flair by Phil Martin. AFAIK it hasn't been digitized yet.  
Read [a great interview](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414061711/http:/typographica.org/000852.php) by [Mark Simonson](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414061711/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Mark%20Simonson) at [Typographica](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414061711/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typographica).

Donuts -- is there anything they can't do?  
-- H. Simpson.

Ray Larabies [Coolvetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414061711/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/larabie/coolvetica/) offers a few swashesque details. Well, the G at least. It's for free.
